ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This semester, we read selections from the maqama genre, mostly al-Hamadhani and al-Hariri. The emphasis in class was on comprehension because these texts are super difficult.
I certainly learned more than I ever would have about the genre of maqamat.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Class was interesting but somewhat disorganized. Assignments were sporadic (on average, around once every other week, often with only 2-3 days' notice), so the workload was very uneven over the course of the semester. It takes a while to get used to the maqama genre, but it is fun once you figure out how it works.
The organization of the course was low, but the sessions themselves were valuable.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The Arabic seminar focuses on a different topic each semester, and it's very much worth taking if you are interested in the subject matter and/or want to improve your Classical Arabic. And Professor Toorawa is great!
Anyone interested in Arabic literature would have to take this course, as one cannot ignore maqamat in that field.
